00028 #if !defined(_SPANDSP_DTMF_H_)
00029 #define _SPANDSP_DTMF_H_

00031 /*! \page dtmf_rx_page DTMF receiver
00032 \section dtmf_rx_page_sec_1 What does it do?
00033 The DTMF receiver detects the standard DTMF digits. It is compliant with
00034 ITU-T Q.23, ITU-T Q.24, and the local DTMF specifications of most administrations.
00035 Its passes the test suites. It also scores *very* well on the standard
00036 talk-off tests. 
00037 
00038 The current design uses floating point extensively. It is not tolerant of DC.
00039 It is expected that a DC restore stage will be placed before the DTMF detector.
00040 Unless the dial tone filter is switched on, the detector has poor tolerance
00041 of dial tone. Whether this matter depends on your application. If you are using
00042 the detector in an IVR application you will need proper echo cancellation to
00043 get good performance in the presence of speech prompts, so dial tone will not
00044 exist. If you do need good dial tone tolerance, a dial tone filter can be
00045 enabled in the detector.
00046 
00047 The DTMF receiver's design assumes the channel is free of any DC component.
00048 
00049 \section dtmf_rx_page_sec_2 How does it work?
00050 Like most other DSP based DTMF detector's, this one uses the Goertzel algorithm
00051 to look for the DTMF tones. What makes each detector design different is just how
00052 that algorithm is used.
00053 
00054 Basic DTMF specs:
00055     - Minimum tone on = 40ms
00056     - Minimum tone off = 50ms
00057     - Maximum digit rate = 10 per second
00058     - Normal twist <= 8dB accepted
00059     - Reverse twist <= 4dB accepted
00060     - S/N >= 15dB will detect OK
00061     - Attenuation <= 26dB will detect OK
00062     - Frequency tolerance +- 1.5% will detect, +-3.5% will reject
00063 
00064 TODO:
00065 */
00066 
00067 /*! \page dtmf_tx_page DTMF tone generation
00068 \section dtmf_tx_page_sec_1 What does it do?
00069 
00070 The DTMF tone generation module provides for the generation of the
00071 repertoire of 16 DTMF dual tones. 
00072 
00073 \section dtmf_tx_page_sec_2 How does it work?
00074 */
00075 
00076 #define MAX_DTMF_DIGITS 128
00077 
00078 typedef void (*digits_rx_callback_t)(void *user_data, const char *digits, int len);
00079 
00080 /*!
00081     DTMF generator state descriptor. This defines the state of a single
00082     working instance of a DTMF generator.
00083 */
00084 typedef struct dtmf_tx_state_s dtmf_tx_state_t;
00085 
00086 /*!
00087     DTMF digit detector descriptor.
00088 */
00089 typedef struct dtmf_rx_state_s dtmf_rx_state_t;
00090 
00091 #if defined(__cplusplus)
00092 extern "C"
00093 {
00094 #endif
00095 
00096 /*! \brief Generate a buffer of DTMF tones.
00097     \param s The DTMF generator context.
00098     \param amp The buffer for the generated signal.
00099     \param max_samples The required number of generated samples.
00100     \return The number of samples actually generated. This may be less than 
00101             max_samples if the input buffer empties. */
00102 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_tx(dtmf_tx_state_t *s, int16_t amp[], int max_samples);
00103 
00104 /*! \brief Put a string of digits in a DTMF generator's input buffer.
00105     \param s The DTMF generator context.
00106     \param digits The string of digits to be added.
00107     \param len The length of the string of digits. If negative, the string is
00108            assumed to be a NULL terminated string.
00109     \return The number of digits actually added. This may be less than the
00110             length of the digit string, if the buffer fills up. */
00111 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_tx_put(dtmf_tx_state_t *s, const char *digits, int len);
00112 
00113 /*! \brief Change the transmit level for a DTMF tone generator context.
00114     \param s The DTMF generator context.
00115     \param level The level of the low tone, in dBm0.
00116     \param twist The twist, in dB. */
00117 SPAN_DECLARE(void) dtmf_tx_set_level(dtmf_tx_state_t *s, int level, int twist);
00118 
00119 /*! \brief Change the transmit on and off time for a DTMF tone generator context.
00120     \param s The DTMF generator context.
00121     \param on-time The on time, in ms.
00122     \param off_time The off time, in ms. */
00123 SPAN_DECLARE(void) dtmf_tx_set_timing(dtmf_tx_state_t *s, int on_time, int off_time);
00124 
00125 /*! \brief Initialise a DTMF tone generator context.
00126     \param s The DTMF generator context.
00127     \return A pointer to the DTMF generator context. */
00128 SPAN_DECLARE(dtmf_tx_state_t *) dtmf_tx_init(dtmf_tx_state_t *s);
00129 
00130 /*! \brief Release a DTMF tone generator context.
00131     \param s The DTMF tone generator context.
00132     \return 0 for OK, else -1. */
00133 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_tx_release(dtmf_tx_state_t *s);
00134 
00135 /*! \brief Free a DTMF tone generator context.
00136     \param s The DTMF tone generator context.
00137     \return 0 for OK, else -1. */
00138 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_tx_free(dtmf_tx_state_t *s);
00139 
00140 /*! Set a optional realtime callback for a DTMF receiver context. This function
00141     is called immediately a confirmed state change occurs in the received DTMF. It
00142     is called with the ASCII value for a DTMF tone pair, or zero to indicate no tone
00143     is being received.
00144     \brief Set a realtime callback for a DTMF receiver context.
00145     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00146     \param callback Callback routine used to report the start and end of digits.
00147     \param user_data An opaque pointer which is associated with the context,
00148            and supplied in callbacks. */
00149 SPAN_DECLARE(void) dtmf_rx_set_realtime_callback(dtmf_rx_state_t *s,
00150                                                  tone_report_func_t callback,
00151                                                  void *user_data);
00152 
00153 /*! \brief Adjust a DTMF receiver context.
00154     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00155     \param filter_dialtone TRUE to enable filtering of dialtone, FALSE
00156            to disable, < 0 to leave unchanged.
00157     \param twist Acceptable twist, in dB. < 0 to leave unchanged.
00158     \param reverse_twist Acceptable reverse twist, in dB. < 0 to leave unchanged.
00159     \param threshold The minimum acceptable tone level for detection, in dBm0.
00160            <= -99 to leave unchanged. */
00161 SPAN_DECLARE(void) dtmf_rx_parms(dtmf_rx_state_t *s,
00162                                  int filter_dialtone,
00163                                  int twist,
00164                                  int reverse_twist,
00165                                  int threshold);
00166 
00167 /*! Process a block of received DTMF audio samples.
00168     \brief Process a block of received DTMF audio samples.
00169     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00170     \param amp The audio sample buffer.
00171     \param samples The number of samples in the buffer.
00172     \return The number of samples unprocessed. */
00173 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_rx(dtmf_rx_state_t *s, const int16_t amp[], int samples);
00174 
00175 /*! Get the status of DTMF detection during processing of the last audio
00176     chunk.
00177     \brief Get the status of DTMF detection during processing of the last
00178            audio chunk.
00179     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00180     \return The current digit status. Either 'x' for a "maybe" condition, or the
00181             digit being detected. */
00182 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_rx_status(dtmf_rx_state_t *s);
00183 
00184 /*! \brief Get a string of digits from a DTMF receiver's output buffer.
00185     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00186     \param digits The buffer for the received digits.
00187     \param max The maximum  number of digits to be returned,
00188     \return The number of digits actually returned. */
00189 SPAN_DECLARE(size_t) dtmf_rx_get(dtmf_rx_state_t *s, char *digits, int max);
00190 
00191 /*! \brief Initialise a DTMF receiver context.
00192     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00193     \param callback An optional callback routine, used to report received digits. If
00194            no callback routine is set, digits may be collected, using the dtmf_rx_get()
00195            function.
00196     \param user_data An opaque pointer which is associated with the context,
00197            and supplied in callbacks.
00198     \return A pointer to the DTMF receiver context. */
00199 SPAN_DECLARE(dtmf_rx_state_t *) dtmf_rx_init(dtmf_rx_state_t *s,
00200                                              digits_rx_callback_t callback,
00201                                              void *user_data);
00202 
00203 /*! \brief Release a DTMF receiver context.
00204     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00205     \return 0 for OK, else -1. */
00206 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_rx_release(dtmf_rx_state_t *s);
00207 
00208 /*! \brief Free a DTMF receiver context.
00209     \param s The DTMF receiver context.
00210     \return 0 for OK, else -1. */
00211 SPAN_DECLARE(int) dtmf_rx_free(dtmf_rx_state_t *s);

00213 #if defined(__cplusplus)
00214 }
